msContents.summary: A Karaim translation of the Torah and the Haftarah

ab.title: Leviticus 25
ab.l:
And the Lord spoke
to Moses on Mount Sinai, saying,

‘Speak to the children of Israel, and say to them, “When you come
to the land which I give you, then the land shall keep a Sabbath
for the Lord.

Six years you shall sow your field,
and six years you shall prune your vineyard, and you shall gather its produce.

And in the seventh year shall be a Sabbath of complete rest to the land,
a Sabbath for the Lord: you shall not sow your field and
you shall not prune your vineyard.

That which grows of its own accord of your harvest you shall not reap,
and you shall not gather the dispersed grapes. It shall be a year of complete rest
to the land.

And the Sabbath of the land shall be for food for you:
for you and for your servants and maidservants and for your hired man and for your settler that
lives with you,

And for your livestock, and
for the wild animals that are in your land shall be all its produce to eat.

And
you shall count seven Sabbaths of years for you: seven times seven years.
And the days of the seven Sabbaths of years will be for you forty-nine
years.

And you shall have the calling voice of the trumpet pass
in the seventh month, on the tenth day of the month: on the
day of atonement you shall have the voice of the trumpet pass through all your land.

And you shall hallow the year of the fiftieth year and proclaim
liberty in the land to all the inhabitants thereof. It is a jubilee, it shall be
liberty for you. And you shall return every man to his possession, and
you shall return, every man to his family.

The year of the fiftieth year is a jubilee,
it shall be for you. You shall not sow, you shall not reap that which grows of itself
in it and you shall not gather what is dispersed of it.

Because it is a year of jubilee. It shall be holy to you. You shall eat from the field.
its produce.

In the year of this jubilee you shall return every
man to his possession.

And if you sell anything
to your fellow or buy anything of your fellow’s hand,
you shall not torment one his brother.

You shall buy from your fellow by the number of years after the jubilee,
by the number of years of crops he shall sell to you:

According to the multitude of years you shall increase its selling price,
and according to the fewness of years you shall diminish the selling price of it,
because according to the number of crops he sells to you.

You shall not torment one another, but you shall fear your God, because I am
the Lord your God.

And you shall do my statutes
and keep my judgments and do them, and
then you will dwell in the land securely.

And the land will give its fruit, and you will eat to the full, and
you will dwell on it securely.

And
if you shall say, “What shall we eat, if in the seventh year we may not sow
or gather in our produce?”

Then I will command
my blessing on you in the sixth year, and
it will make grow the produce for three years.

And
you will sow the eighth year and eat the old produce
until the ninth year: you will eat the old |produce| until its produce arrives to you.

The land shall not be sold †forever, because
the land is mine, because you are strangers and settlers with me.

And in all the land of your possession you shall give a redemption
for the land.

If your brother becomes poor and sells any of his possession,
then his closest relative shall come and shall redeem
his brother’s sale.

And a man who has no
relative, but his hand can attain it and he finds enough for his redemption:

Then let him count the years of his sale and
restore what has increased to the man to whom he sold it, and
he shall return to his possession.

And if his hand has not found
enough to restore it to him, his sale shall be
in the hand of the one who bought it until the year of jubilee, and
it shall come out in the jubilee, and he shall return to his possession.

And a man who sells a dwelling house in a walled city:
its redemption shall be until the end of the year of its sale — there shall be a year
for its redemption.

And if it is not redeemed by the completion of a
full year, then the house that is in the walled city shall be established
†forever to the one who bought it throughout his generations. It shall not come out even in the jubilee.

And the houses of the homesteads which have no wall
around them shall be counted as the fields of the country. It shall
have redemption, and it shall come out in the jubilee.

And the cities of the Levites,
the houses of the cities of their possession: the Levites shall have eternal redemption.

And if one of the Levites redeems: then it comes out, a sale
of a house or a city of his possession, in the jubilee, because the houses of the cities
of the Levites are their possession among the sons
of Israel.

But the field of pastureland of their cities
shall not be sold, for it is their eternal possession.

And
if your brother becomes poor and his hand slips with you, then
you shall strengthen him — a stranger or a setter — and he shall live with you.

Do not take interest or profit from him, but you shall fear your God, and
your brother shall live with you.

You shall not lend him your silver
for interest, and you shall not give him your grain for profit.

I am the Lord your God, who brought you out from the land of Egypt,
to give you the land of Canaan, to be God to you.

And if your brother becomes poor beside you and
is sold to you, you shall not make him work a servant’s work.
He shall be like a settler, he shall serve you until the year of jubilee.

And then he shall go out from you, he and
his children with him, and shall return to his own family and
to the possession of his fathers shall he return.

For they are my servants,
whom I brought out from the land of Egypt. They shall not be sold like the sale
of a servant.

You shall not rule over him oppressively, but
shall fear your God.

And your servants and maidservants that you shall have
shall be of the kingdoms that are around you: you shall buy servants
and maidservants from them.

And also from the children of the settlers who
live with you: you shall buy from them and of their families
that are with you, whom they begat in your land. And they shall become
a possession for you.

And you shall take them as an inheritance
for your children after you, to inherit as a possession.
You shall make them work forever. But your brothers, the children of Israel —
a man toward his brother: you shall not rule over them oppressively.

And if the hand of a stranger and settler with you attains it,
and your brother with him becomes poor and sells himself to the stranger |and| settler
with you or to a godless of the stranger’s family:

After he is sold he shall have redemption. One of his brothers shall redeem
him.

Either his uncle or his uncle’s son shall redeem
him, or a close relative to his body of his family shall redeem him; or
if his hand can attain it, he shall redeem himself.

And
he shall calculate himself with the one who buys him from the year that he was sold to him
to the year of jubilee: and the silver of his sale shall be
by the number of years. Its shall be with him like the days of a hired worker.

If
there are still many years, he shall pay back his redemption according to them
from the silver that he was bought for.

And if a few years remain
to the year of jubilee, he shall calculate it for him. According
to his years shall he return him the silver of his redemption.

As a hired servant he shall be with him every year, and he shall not rule over him
oppressively in your sight.

And if he is not redeemed
in these |years|, he shall go out in the year of jubilee, he and his children with him.

Because the children of Israel are servants to me. They are my servants,
whom I brought out from the land of Egypt. I am the Lord your God.

You shall make no vanities for yourselves, and you shall not set up a carved idol or a pillar
for yourselves and you shall not set up any engraved stones in your land
to bow down over it, because I am the Lord your God.

You shall keep my Sabbaths and fear my sanctuary. I am the Lord.
Parashat Bechukotai

app.note: An uncertain translation of ovelikḱa, cf. Heb. לַצְּמִיתֻת ‘forever’.
